topic.title: [Questions] Can "data" folder be encrypt on the fly?
topic.body:
I believe encrypting data on the user pc is essential when someone (ie. government agencies) tries to get access to the visitors data.

The goal of ZeroNet is to create decentralized censorship-resistant network, but you see, you need seeders to keep the network alive. Nobody wants to be seeder if the data on there computer is not ensure to be secure.

Why not full disk encryption?
Full disk encryption does protect against 3rd party access to data, but it does not protect the visitors. Example of this is that many person have been convict for not decrypting the disk.

So how is this different?
You see, the thing that file encryption have over full disk encryption is Plausible deniability

You can have sensitive files on your pc, securely delete it, and let 3rd party look over your pc. Pretending to be innocent.

I don't think ZeroNet will have this feature soon. So I would like to know if there is external application that encrypt the "data" folder for me?
